natural problem: For what value of the constant $a$ does the system of equations below have infinitely many solutions?   \begin{align*} 3x + 2y &= 8,\\ 6x &= 2a - 7 - 4y \end{align*}
natural solution: First we bring all the $x$ and $y$ terms to the left, and put all the other terms on the right. This makes our system \begin{align} 3x+2y &=8,\\ 6x+4y&= 2a-7. \end{align}Multiplying the first equation by 2 makes its coefficients of $x$ and $y$ match those of the second equation: \begin{align} 6x+4y &=16,\\ 6x+4y&= 2a-7.

\end{align}If $2a-7=16$, these equations will be the same, so the system will have infinitely many solutions. If $2a-7$ does not equal 16, then this system will have no solutions, since $6x+4y$ cannot equal two different numbers.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a x y :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. 3 * x + 2 * y = 8"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. 6 * x = 2 * a - 7 - 4 * y"
shows  "a = 23 / 2"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 For what value of the constant $a$ does the system of equations below have infinitely many solutions?   \begin{align*} 3x + 2y &= 8,\\ 6x &= 2a - 7 - 4y \end{align*} The final Answer is \frac{23}{2}
 ### Proof
 First we bring all the $x$ and $y$ terms to the left, and put all the other terms on the right. This makes our system \begin{align} 3x+2y &=8,\\ 6x+4y&= 2a-7. \end{align}Multiplying the first equation by 2 makes its coefficients of $x$ and $y$ match those of the second equation: \begin{align} 6x+4y &=16,\\ 6x+4y&= 2a-7.
 \end{align}If $2a-7=16$, these equations will be the same, so the system will have infinitely many solutions. If $2a-7$ does not equal 16, then this system will have no solutions, since $6x+4y$ cannot equal two different numbers.
 Solving $2a-7=16$ gives us $a=\boxed{\frac{23}{2}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a x y :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. 3 * x + 2 * y = 8"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. 6 * x = 2 * a - 7 - 4 * y"
shows  "a = 23 / 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the value of $a$ such that the system of equations $\begin{cases} 3x + 2y = 8 \\ 6x = 2a - 7 - 4y \end{cases}$ has a solution for $x$ and $y$. The final answer is $\frac{23}{2}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y a :: real
assumes h0 : "3 * x + 2 * y = 8"
and h1 : "6 * x = 2 * a - 7 - 4 * y"
shows  "\<exists> a. \<forall> x y. (3 * x + 2 * y = 8) \<and> (6 * x = 2 * a - 7 - 4 * y) \<and> a = 23 / 2"

(* ### Problem

This makes our system \begin{align} 3x+2y &=8,\\ 6x+4y&= 2a-7. \end{align}Multiplying the first equation by 2 makes its coefficients of $x$ and $y$ match those of the second equation: \begin{align} 6x+4y &=16,\\ 6x+4y&= 2a-7.
 \end{align}If $2a-7=16$, these equations will be the same, so the system will have infinitely many solutions. If $2a-7$ does not equal 16, then this system will have no solutions, since $6x+4y$ cannot equal two different numbers.
 Solving $2a-7=16$ gives us $a=\boxed{\frac{23}{2}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x y a :: real
assumes h0 : "3 * x + 2 * y = 8"
and h1 : "6 * x = 2 * a - 7 - 4 * y"
shows  "\<exists> a. \<forall> x y. (3 * x + 2 * y = 8) \<and> (6 * x = 2 * a - 7 - 4 * y) \<and> a = 23 / 2"

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a x y :: real
assumes h0 : "3 * x + 2 * y = 8"
and h1 : "6 * x = 2 * a - 7 - 4 * y"
and h2 : "infinite {x, y}"
shows  "a = 23 / 2"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 For what value of the constant $a$ does the system of equations below have infinitely many solutions?   \begin{align*} 3x + 2y &= 8,\\ 6x &= 2a - 7 - 4y \end{align*} The final Answer is \frac{23}{2}
 ### Proof
 First we bring all the $x$ and $y$ terms to the left, and put all the other terms on the right. This makes our system \begin{align} 3x+2y &=8,\\ 6x+4y&= 2a-7. \end{align}Multiplying the first equation by 2 makes its coefficients of $x$ and $y$ match those of the second equation: \begin{align} 6x+4y &=16,\\ 6x+4y&= 2a-7.
 \end{align}If $2a-7=16$, these equations will be the same, so the system will have infinitely many solutions. If $2a-7$ does not equal 16, then this system will have no solutions, since $6x+4y$ cannot equal two different numbers.
 Solving $2a-7=16$ gives us $a=\boxed{\frac{23}{2}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a x y :: real
assumes h0 : "3 * x + 2 * y = 8"
and h1 : "6 * x = 2 * a - 7 - 4 * y"
and h2 : "infinite {x, y}"
shows  "a = 23 / 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem:
Given an infinite number of ordered pairs $(x, y)$ that satisfy the system of equations:
$3x + 2y = 8$ and $6x = 2a - 7 - 4y$,
find the value of $a$. The final answer is $\frac{23}{2}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y a :: real
assumes h0 : "3 * x + 2 * y = 8"
and h1 : "6 * x = 2 * a - 7 - 4 * y"
and h2 : "\<exists> k. \<forall> x y. k * (3 * x + 2 * y) = 6 * x"
shows  "a = 23 / 2"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 For what value of the constant $a$ does the system of equations below have infinitely many solutions?   \begin{align*} 3x + 2y &= 8,\\ 6x &= 2a - 7 - 4y \end{align*} The final Answer is \frac{23}{2}
 ### Proof
 First we bring all the $x$ and $y$ terms to the left, and put all the other terms on the right. This makes our system \begin{align} 3x+2y &=8,\\ 6x+4y&= 2a-7. \end{align}Multiplying the first equation by 2 makes its coefficients of $x$ and $y$ match those of the second equation: \begin{align} 6x+4y &=16,\\ 6x+4y&= 2a-7.
 \end{align}If $2a-7=16$, these equations will be the same, so the system will have infinitely many solutions. If $2a-7$ does not equal 16, then this system will have no solutions, since $6x+4y$ cannot equal two different numbers.
 Solving $2a-7=16$ gives us $a=\boxed{\frac{23}{2}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x y a :: real
assumes h0 : "3 * x + 2 * y = 8"
and h1 : "6 * x = 2 * a - 7 - 4 * y"
and h2 : "\<exists> k. \<forall> x y. k * (3 * x + 2 * y) = 6 * x"
shows  "a = 23 / 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Given that $3x + 2y = 8$ and $6x = 2a - 7 - 4y$, find the value of $a$ if there exists a constant $k$ such that $k(3x + 2y) = 6x$ for all values of $x$ and $y$. The final answer is $\frac{23}{2}$.

 Solving $2a-7=16$ gives us $a=\boxed{\frac{23}{2}}$.

assumes h0 : "3 * x + 2 * y = 8"

The final answer is $\frac{23}{2}$.
